misconceptions.name: Hardcoding the grade instead of reading it from user input
misconceptions.description: The program assigns a fixed grade value (95) and never reads the grade from the user, so it cannot work for arbitrary inputs as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it is acceptable to set the grade directly in code (e.g., 95) instead of reading it from the user for this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user and read the numeric grade (0–100) from the keyboard (e.g., using Scanner.nextInt or nextDouble), then compute and print the letter grade based on that input.
symptoms: The variable grade is initialized with a constant value (95).
No Scanner call (nextInt/nextDouble) is used to assign a value to grade.
The letter grade output is always computed for 95, regardless of what the user types earlier.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or focus on reusing previous distance-calculation code without adapting input handling for the grade task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded declaration int grade = 95; with code that reads the grade from the user, such as: System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();
related_concepts: Separation of concerns between different tasks in one file
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only assignment to grade is a literal 95, and there is no other input related to grades; this clearly contradicts the requirement to read a numeric grade.

evidence.note: grade is given a fixed literal value (95) immediately before the grading logic, and there is no Scanner call to read a grade from the user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using overlapping independent if statements for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses several independent if statements with only lower-bound checks (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60) instead of mutually exclusive conditions or an if–else-if chain, causing higher grades to match multiple ranges and print multiple letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that separate if statements with overlapping conditions will each represent distinct grade ranges, or that only the first matching if will run even without else-if.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, each if statement is evaluated independently. If multiple if conditions are true, all their bodies will execute. For grade ranges that must be mutually exclusive (A, B, C, D, F), either use an if–else-if–else chain or write non-overlapping Boolean conditions that include appropriate upper and lower bounds.
symptoms: For grade = 95, all of A, B, C, and D conditions are true, so multiple letter grades would be printed.
For a mid-range grade like 75, both the C and D conditions are true, leading to two letter outputs.
Only F has an exclusive range (grade < 60); the others are overlapping thresholds.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between how independent if statements work versus an if–else-if chain, and lack of attention to overlapping numeric ranges when using only lower-bound checks.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly uses only lower-bound checks with separate if statements for each grade tier; this pattern deterministically causes overlapping matches for high grades.

evidence.note: All grade thresholds (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60) are checked with independent if statements, so a high grade like 95 will satisfy multiple conditions and cause multiple letter grades to print.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding Input Value
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded the variable 'grade' to 95 instead of using the Scanner object to read the numeric grade from user input as required by the assignment prompt. They also included unrelated input logic for distance calculation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that either hardcoding the value satisfies the requirement, or they failed to adapt existing code properly for input, resulting in an unexecutable requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must interactively request and read the grade from the system input (keyboard) using a Scanner object.
symptoms: The program output is the same regardless of what the user types (when it asks for x1, y1, etc.)
The grade calculation always uses '95'
Unrelated code (distance calculation) is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to appropriately adapt existing code or misinterpreting the 'reads a numeric grade' requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the unrelated distance calculation code and replace the hardcoded 'int grade=95;' with a line that prompts the user and reads a grade using the existing 'input' Scanner object.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly initializes 'grade' to 95 and does not read it from the user.

evidence.note: Includes irrelevant input reading logic from another problem.
Grade value is hardcoded instead of being read from input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect Conditional Control Flow for Mutually Exclusive Ranges
misconceptions.description: The student used multiple independent 'if' statements instead of a linked 'if-else if-else' structure. Since a higher grade satisfies all conditions below it (e.g., 95 is >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60), the program will incorrectly print multiple letter grades for a single score (A, B, C, D, in this case), failing to correctly implement the required grade ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that sequential 'if' statements are sufficient to categorize mutually exclusive ranges like grade levels, failing to account for the fact that conditions are not exclusive unless explicitly made so (e.g., using '&&' or 'else if').
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges are mutually exclusive. To handle this in code, use an 'if-else if-else' structure so that once a condition is met, no further conditions are checked, or use compound boolean conditions (e.g., `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`).
symptoms: Multiple lines of output (multiple grades displayed)
The logic for A implicitly includes B, C, and D because the control flow continues
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how independent 'if' statements vs. 'if-else if' structures determine control flow and enforce mutual exclusivity.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Chain your grade checks using 'else if'. For example: `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else { ... }`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The sequence of five independent 'if' statements checking inclusive minimum thresholds (>= 90, >= 80, etc.) is the clearest diagnostic symptom of this core logical error.

evidence.note: Independent 'if' statements cause high grades to print multiple letter grades.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem implementation - solving distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a completely different program (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator requested in Q3. This shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not understanding that the assignment asks for a grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q3 explicitly asks for a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Uses distance formula Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1))
Hardcoded grade value of 95 at the end
No actual input reading for the grade from the user
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student copied code from a different assignment or failed to read the problem statement carefully before implementing the solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. Start fresh with a simple program that: (1) reads one numeric input (the grade), (2) uses if/else statements to check ranges, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure is dedicated to solving a distance calculation problem with hardcoded grade logic at the end. This is unambiguously not the grade calculator requested.

evidence.note: This entire section reads coordinates and calculates distance, which is completely unrelated to grade calculation.
The grade is hardcoded as a constant rather than being read from user input as required.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect conditional logic - missing else-if chain
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements instead of an if-else chain. This causes all conditions to be checked even after one matches, resulting in multiple outputs for a single grade (e.g., grade 95 would print both 'A' and 'B').
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that using separate if statements will correctly select one grade level, without understanding that all conditions are evaluated independently.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When checking mutually exclusive conditions (a grade can only be one letter), use if-else-if chains so that only one branch executes. Once a condition is true, subsequent conditions should not be checked.
symptoms: Multiple if statements without else clauses
For grade 95: would print 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D' (all conditions >=60 are true)
Program violates the logic that a grade maps to exactly one letter
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how conditional statements work - specifically, not recognizing that if statements evaluate independently and that else-if is needed for mutually exclusive cases.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the series of independent if statements with if-else-if-else chain: if(grade>=90) {...} else if(grade>=80) {...} else if(grade>=70) {...} else if(grade>=60) {...} else {...}
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows independent if statements that would all evaluate true for a single grade value, demonstrating a fundamental misunderstanding of control flow.

evidence.note: Five independent if statements without else clauses. For grade=95, all of the first four conditions are true, so the program would print A, B, C, and D.

misconceptions.name: Not reading the grade from user input (misinterpreting problem requirements)
misconceptions.description: The student hard-codes `int grade = 95;` instead of reading the numeric grade from the keyboard as the problem statement requires. This indicates a misunderstanding that the program must work for arbitrary user-provided grades, not just a fixed test value.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can assign a fixed value to `grade` in the code (e.g., `grade = 95`) and that is sufficient to satisfy 'reads a numeric grade (0-100)'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use input (e.g., `Scanner`) to read a grade supplied by the user at runtime. Hard-coding a test value does not satisfy the requirement to read a numeric grade.
symptoms: The program never asks the user for a grade value.
The grade is always 95 regardless of what the user types.
The instructions to 'read a numeric grade (0-100)' are not followed.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements and reliance on a fixed test value rather than dynamic input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Replace the hard-coded `int grade = 95;` with a `Scanner` read, such as:
`System.out.print("Enter grade: ");`
`int grade = input.nextInt();`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only grade value in the program is a literal `95` assigned directly to `grade`, and there is no input operation that reads a grade.

evidence.note: The program computes a distance and then sets `grade` to a fixed value of 95 instead of reading it from input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using overlapping independent if statements for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent `if` statements that only check lower bounds (`>= 90`, `>= 80`, `>= 70`, `>= 60`) instead of mutually exclusive ranges or an `if`/`else if` chain. This means that a single grade can satisfy several conditions and produce multiple letter outputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: To implement a grade scale, it is enough to check if `grade >= 90`, `grade >= 80`, `grade >= 70`, and `grade >= 60` in separate `if` statements, and the correct single letter will be printed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade ranges must be mutually exclusive: for any given grade, exactly one condition should be true. This is usually implemented with an `if`/`else if`/`else` chain or with conditions that include both lower and upper bounds (e.g., `grade >= 80 && grade < 90`).
symptoms: For grade 95, the program prints A, B, C, and D.
For grade 85, the program prints B, C, and D.
Multiple letter grades are printed for a single numeric grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how Boolean conditions interact when multiple overlapping conditions are checked independently, and lack of understanding of mutually exclusive ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Rewrite the conditions as a single chain, for example:
`if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }`
This guarantees that only one branch executes for any grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All grade thresholds are checked using separate `if` statements with only lower bounds, a classic pattern that leads directly to multiple outputs.

evidence.note: All conditions are separate `if` statements using only lower bounds; a grade like 95 satisfies all of the first four conditions, producing multiple letters.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding Input Value
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded the grade value (`int grade=95;`) instead of reading the numeric grade from the standard input (keyboard) as required by the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to assign a sample value to the variable to demonstrate the logic, or the student forgot to use the `Scanner` object they initialized.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The variable must be assigned the value read from the input stream using the `Scanner` object (e.g., `input.nextInt();`) to fulfill the requirement of 'reading a numeric grade'.
symptoms: Variable is assigned a literal value instead of a method call to read input.
Program output is the same regardless of what the user types.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpreting or ignoring the 'read a numeric grade' requirement of the prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how to use the 'Scanner' class to read different data types from the console and replace the hardcoded assignment with an input reading call.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct violation of the input requirement, clearly demonstrated by the snippet.

evidence.note: Grade value is hardcoded (95) instead of being read from standard input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Failing to use mutually exclusive conditions (Cascading IFs)
misconceptions.description: The student used multiple independent `if` statements for mutually exclusive ranges (A, B, C, D), causing grades that meet a higher threshold (like 95) to satisfy all subsequent lower thresholds (95 >= 80, 95 >= 70, etc.). This results in the program printing multiple letter grades for a single input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The compiler checks the conditions sequentially, and separate `if` statements are sufficient to cover distinct ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grade calculation requires conditional logic that ensures mutual exclusivity. This is typically achieved using `if-else if-else if...else` structures or by explicitly defining the lower bound for each range (e.g., `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)`).
symptoms: Multiple outputs are generated when only one is expected.
The logic fails to define correct grade boundaries.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding about how independent `if` statements (versus `if-else if`) control program flow and enforce mutual exclusion of conditions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Refactor the grading logic to use `if (conditionA) { actionA } else if (conditionB) { actionB } ... else { actionF }` so that only one grade is printed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structural misuse of sequential `if` statements for range checking is evident across all defined grade levels (A, B, C, D).

evidence.note: Independent 'if' statements are used, causing incorrect cascading output. E.g., a grade of 95 prints A, B, C, and D.

misconceptions.name: Code for unrelated task included in submission
misconceptions.description: The submission includes code for performing a distance calculation (reading four coordinates and calculating distance) which is irrelevant to the 'Grade Calculator' problem (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either mistook this file for another assignment or copied existing unrelated initialization code without deleting the unnecessary logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Submissions should only contain code relevant to the specific problem being solved.
symptoms: Excessive input reading for undefined variables (x1, y1, x2, y2).
Calculations leading to an irrelevant result ('The distance of the two points is...').
misconceptions.root_cause: Poor organization or failure to clean up template/scaffolding code from another problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code is clean and only performs the actions required by the specific question.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The first nine lines of the main method are clearly dedicated to calculating the distance between two points, a task completely separate from the grade calculator.

evidence.note: This code segment is for calculating distance between points, not for Q3 (Grade Calculator).

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Cascading if statements instead of else-if chains
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements to check grade ranges instead of if-else if chains. This means all conditions will be evaluated independently, causing multiple letter grades to print for a single input (e.g., grades 90+ will print both 'A' and 'B' and 'C' and 'D').
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that using sequential if statements (if, if, if, if, if) will correctly isolate the grade into a single category.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For mutually exclusive conditions, use if-else if chains so that only one branch executes: if(grade>=90) {...} else if(grade>=80) {...} else if(grade>=70) {...} else if(grade>=60) {...} else {...}. This ensures each grade falls into exactly one category.
symptoms: A grade of 95 would print: A, B, C, and D (all four lines execute)
Multiple letter grades printed for a single grade value
Logic fails the basic requirement that each grade should map to exactly one letter
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstand of how conditional flow works with independent if statements versus if-else if chains. The student may not realize that all if conditions are independently evaluated when not connected with else.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the chain of if statements with if-else if: Change 'if(grade>=80)' to 'else if(grade>=80)', 'if(grade>=70)' to 'else if(grade>=70)', etc. This ensures only the first matching condition executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern is clear in the code: five independent if statements checking overlapping ranges (>=90, >=80, >=70, >=60, <60). For a grade of 95, all conditions except <60 would be true, causing multiple outputs. This directly contradicts the requirement.

evidence.note: Five independent if statements with overlapping conditions. A grade of 95 satisfies >=90, >=80, >=70, and >=60, so all four letters would print instead of just 'A'.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded test value instead of reading input
misconceptions.description: The student hardcodes the grade value as `int grade=95;` instead of reading it from Scanner input. This completely ignores the requirement to read the grade from the user, and the program will always use 95 regardless of what the user enters.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either forgotten to implement input reading or misunderstood that the grade must come from user input rather than being hardcoded.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read the numeric grade from user input using Scanner. The correct approach is: `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();` to prompt the user and read their input.
symptoms: Program does not prompt the user to enter a grade (missing 'Enter grade:' prompt)
Program always processes the same hardcoded value (95) regardless of user input
Program output will not match sample run where user inputs 85
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either forgot to implement the input-reading step or failed to understand that the problem requires dynamic user input rather than testing with hardcoded values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a prompt and read the grade using Scanner: Add `System.out.print("Enter grade: ");` before the assignment, then change `int grade=95;` to `int grade=input.nextInt();`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows `int grade=95;` with no input prompt. The student has Scanner imported and used earlier in the code (for x1, y1, x2, y2), so they know how to use it, but failed to apply it to reading the grade.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95 instead of being read from Scanner input. No prompt for user input appears.
